instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.SMC_BCACOK: What is SMC_BCACOK? This is a typo of SMC_BC_ACOK When you see SMC_BCACOK, assume they meant to type SMC_BC_ACOK.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.CHGR_ACOK: What is CHGR_ACOK? This is identical to SMC_BC_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.BC_ACOK: What is BC_ACOK? This is a typo of SMC_BC_ACOK. When you see BC_ACOK, assume they meant to type SMC_BC_ACOK.
definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CHGR_ACIN: What is CHGR_ACIN? CHGR_ACIN is a signal that is created by a voltage divider between the charger and ground that goes into the ISL6258, ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip that creates PPBUS_G3H. It is necessary for SMC_BC_ACOK & CHGR_ACOK to be present so that the onewire circuit is told to turn on & allow the SMC to speak to the charger..
definitions.CPUIMVP_VR_ON: What is CPUIMVP_VR_ON? CPUIMVP_VR_ON is a signal that tells the buck converter responsible for PPVCORE_S0_CPU to turn on and create CPU vcore voltage. This comes from ALL_SYS_PWRGD – once ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present, CPUIMVP_VR_ON will be present. .
definitions.SMBUS_CHGR_SDA: What is SMBUS_CHGR_SDA? SMBUS_CHGR_SDA is the data line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..
definitions.SMBUS_CHGR_SCL: What is SMBUS_CHGR_SCL? SMBUS_CHGR_SCL is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED..
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON – CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3V
threads.message:
This board has had some liquid damage on it, sticky crap but not much corrosion.
No or a dim green light, wont power on.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.42V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> is 0 V. Resistance to ground ~22k

<SIGNAL>SMC_BCACOK</SIGNAL> is fluctuating between 3.0 and 3.3V. not steady.
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is 3.42V

[B]already done:[/B]
Fluxed up and heating the SMC to pre-reflow temp. no change
Fluxed and reflowed SMC. still the same deal.

I'm thinking that next on the list may be replacing the SMC, but I'd like to be a bit more sure of that before going there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3V
threads.message: Replace <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. It is PPBUS G3H buck controller and sends out BCACOK. PPBUS is low so may be an SMC but let's try the ISL first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3V
threads.message:
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> replaced. I've checked everything on <SIGNAL>BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> / <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL>. <RESISTOR>R5087</RESISTOR> is 470k as it should be. I've lifted <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> to see if that was mucking it up, but BCACOK stays the same with it removed.

However, I just noticed that <SIGNAL>PPCHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> is fluctuating as well. Its sitting at 16.7V most of the time, but sometimes dips down to 16.0V for a moment. This carries all the way to <SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN</SIGNAL>, where I get 17.1V dropping down to 16.5 every 10 seconds or so.

note: I've already tried swapping the DC in board and the charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3V
threads.message: Dead SMC or crap under it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3V
threads.message:
I've replaced the SMC. Green light went on, machine powered on with fan spinning continuously but no image on screen and no blacklight.
Now that I've had it on and off a few times, it no longer powers on. Instead, it takes 20 seconds or longer for the green light to come on, but its not steady. Keeps on blinking.
Did I botch the SMC replacement or might something else be wrong?

edit - it still powers up right away from another charger.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> still 12.3
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.45
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> - 5.05V

no gong (right or left speaker attached), no image on external screen.

<SIGNAL>LCD_IG_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is at 0V, but no short to ground. (90k). But I'm guessing I need the gong before looking at the LCD, right?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3V
threads.message: 12.3V on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> could be a bad SMC or ISL, also could be a bad soldering on the SMC when it was replaced...  CPU Vcore present???? Any activity on USB???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3V
threads.message:
I'm guessing cpu core being ok or not is this one: [TABLE="border: 0, cellspacing: 0"]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_VR_ON</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"] [/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]3,29V[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[/TABLE]

I've replaced the ISL already. checked a couple of things: [TABLE="border: 0, cellspacing: 0"]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>PPCHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]16,4V[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]4V[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>SMBUS_CHGR_SDA</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]hmm[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>SMBUS_CHGR_SCL</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]3,46V[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_L</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]3,42V[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]3,27V[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>PP5V1_CHGR_VDD</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]5V[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>PP5V1_CHGR_VDDP</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 			[TD="align: left"]5V[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[/TABLE]

I checked <SIGNAL>SMBUS_CHGR_SDA</SIGNAL> on the scope. It looks different when compared to a functional <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B I had lying around. Should be similar, I'd think.

[ATTACH alt="<SIGNAL>SMBUS_CHGR_SDA</SIGNAL>-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-bad.jpg" type="full" width="320px"]26048._xfImport[/ATTACH]

[B]<SIGNAL>SMBUS_CHGR_SDA</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 12.3[/B]

[ATTACH alt="<SIGNAL>SMBUS_CHGR_SDA</SIGNAL>-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-ok.jpg" type="full" width="320px"]26049._xfImport[/ATTACH]

[B]<SIGNAL>SMBUS_CHGR_SDA</SIGNAL> on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> which boots into OS (but is very slow)[/B]

Thats a bidirectional line, but perhaps someone has seen this before and knows whether the most likely suspect is ISL or SMC..

What do you want me to check when you say activity on USB?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3V
threads.message: CPU Vcore present on L7510?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3V
threads.message: Yes it is, 1.12V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3V
threads.message:
I decided to spend some time looking through the schematic in the hopes of gaining some understanding.
This isn't really relevant to this particular board, but bear with me..

I see <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL> found at L7510 comes from <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR>, which requires input on the following pins to generate <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU_PH1_L</SIGNAL>: [TABLE="border: 0, cellspacing: 0"]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_BOOT1</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_PHASE1</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[TR]
[TD="align: left"]<SIGNAL>CPUIMVP_LGATE1</SIGNAL>[/TD]
 		[/TR]
[/TABLE]

<SIGNAL>PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP</SIGNAL> comes from <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>
The other three inputs all come from <CHIP>U7400</CHIP>

<CHIP>U7400</CHIP> deals in CPUIMVP and other CPU related stuff and has a bunch of pins it wants to see something on. Those inputs are several power rails, a bunch of lines from the CPU and a couple from (or at least related to) <TRANSISTOR>Q7510</TRANSISTOR> and <TRANSISTOR>Q7560</TRANSISTOR>, which are part of the phased power supply to the CPU. Did I miss anytihng so far?
Am I correct in saying that measuring L7510 or L7520 lets me see whether <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> [B]and[/B] the CPU are working?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3V
threads.message: If Vcore is present all power rails will be OK. Beep without RAM?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3V
threads.message: Agreed. Even with a dead CPU PPBUS should be 12.56 unless its shorted and holding it down

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3V
threads.message:
I am also not trusting the SMC job I did. :rolleyes:
Or the SMC I used, of course, but when can you trust that?
I will use my other donor board's SMC for another try as soon as I have time. Will report back latah.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3V
threads.message:
I finally got around to replacing the SMC again. When removing the previous one, I noticed that three balls had merged. That may have happened during removal, but I probably bumped the SMC too hard when trying to see if the solder had melted while placing it. The merged balls were: <SIGNAL>LPC_AD</SIGNAL><0>, <SIGNAL>LPC_AD</SIGNAL><2> and <SIGNAL>SMC_WAKE_SCI_L</SIGNAL>

I grabbed another SMC from a donor board, reballed and placed that. Machine would now power on with quarter fan spin. Magsafe light slightly blinking. Every now and then it would go full fan spin, but no beep from speakers. Most of the time its just an endless loop of quarter fan spin.

I first wanted to rule out having messed up the SMC again so decided to replace it yet again, just to see if the behaviour would be the same. This time there were no merged balls when lifting the SMC, and placing the next one went smooth. The board is acting the same as with the second SMC, so I'm assuming the problem is somewhere else. Might be because of the first SMC job, or because there is simply another issue with the board.

Some measurements I took:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 12.58V
<SIGNAL>SMC_BCACOK</SIGNAL> = 3.27V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> = 3.45V
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
L7510 = 0V

[B]Resistance to ground because of the previously merged SMC balls:[/B]
<SIGNAL>LPC_AD</SIGNAL><0> to ground is about 230KOhm    
<SIGNAL>LPC_AD</SIGNAL><2> to ground is 7.18MOhm    
<SIGNAL>SMC_WAKE_SCI_L</SIGNAL> to ground starts at 1k and goes up quickly

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3V
threads.message: Power cycling can be anything. Was <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> already replaced? Checked <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>/03? <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulsing high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3V
threads.message:
I hadn't replaced <CHIP>U2600</CHIP> yet, but I have now. Hasn't changed anything.

<RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR>/3 are 150/181kOhm
<SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is pulsing high

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3V
threads.message: At this point it can be anything. Any knocked off component, any corroded trace/resistor. I really have no more ideas.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no green light, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12.3V
threads.message: I'll inspect the whole thing and see if I find anything of interest. If nothing, I guess I'll have to give up on this one. Hate that :(
